DataElement.preferredName: Gallbladder Cancer AJCC Edition 8 Clinical Distant Metastasis M Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for gallbladder carcinoma based on clinical findings using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A pear-shaped organ located under the liver that stores and concentrates bile secreted by the liver. From the gallbladder the bile is delivered through the bile ducts into the intestine thereby aiding the digestion of fat-containing foods._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity._One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A pear-shaped organ just below the liver that stores the bile secreted by the liver, delivering the bile through the bile ducts into the intestines to help with digestion.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: A pear-shaped organ located under the liver that stores and concentrates bile secreted by the liver. From the gallbladder the bile is delivered through the bile ducts into the intestine thereby aiding the digestion of fat-containing foods.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC Based:Staging Criteria Based on American Joint Committee on Cancer System
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9.29.20 TL transferred context from CTEP to NCI Standards, unretired and versioned DEC (restored Long Name and concept definitions). Orphan DEC Retired Archived as part of caBIG effort to retire orphan Administered Components 01-01-2013 djs

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gallbladder Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 M Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of gallbladder cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This staging system applies to gallbladder carcinomas. Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors and sarcomas are not staged using this staging system. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
